div1.p: The writer discusses endemic centers of yellow fever and the origin of the disease.

div1.head: Memorandum to Michael E. Connor, [19--]

3/ When I began this inquiry I was of the opinion--held tentatively,
as I rather accepted than investigated the data on which the arguments of
Moreau de Jonnes: Cornilliac: Finlay and Beranger Feraud were based: that
yellow fever was of American origin--found in Sto. Domingo (1494) and on
the terra firme when the Spaniards first landed. Since I have been examin-
ing into the bases of these arguments, and from original sources as far as
may be, I am at least doubtful of it being of American origin. I have not,
however, concluded my inquiry and probably will not for several months and,
naturally, will hold my opinion in abeyance until I have done so. Indeed,
I may not find sufficient data to justify a definite opinion. I hope that
I will.

4/ I do not think you will find “xekik” mentioned in any Maya his-
torical record (which has been transcribed in Roman script.) The Maya-cim-
lal (Maya-death) is recorded as occurring in Katun 4 Ahau (1493, Morley:
1495, Landa and Martinez). Xekik is mentioned a number of times as going
to occur, in prophesies and prophetic rituals. The dates of these are not
known, but all I have seen--from the Chilan Balan of Chumayel (photostat)
and some given me by Dr. Martinez from that of Tizimin--are after the great
typhus and relapsing fever epidemic in Mexico, which was truly a “puja-
miento de sangre de la boca y nariz.” The only one dated is dated 1740;
after the yellow fever epidemic of 1648.

5/ I knew, from the experiments of Lopez, that aegypti could feed
and propagate in Mexico City. Are they there in any number? See a letter
I wrote Scannell on this.

6/ When I hear from everybody, I will go over the Epidemiology care-
fully--it is not a careless bit of work as it stands and there is no “fill-
ing” in it--and incorporate some of the suggestions I receive on it: Among
